question: I'm not a drama critic. Well, Mr. Saavik, are you going to stay with the sinking ship?
answer: Permission to speak candidly, sir?

question: Very well.
answer: I don't believe this was a fair test of my command capabilities.

question: And why not?
answer: Because... there was no way to win.

question: A no-win situation is a possibility every commander may face. Has that never occurred to you?
answer: ... No, sir. It has not.

question: How we deal with death is at least as important as how we deal with life, wouldn't you say?
answer: As I indicated, Admiral, that thought had not occurred to me.

question: Aren't you dead? I assume you are loitering here to learn what efficiency rating I plan to give your cadets.
answer: I am understandably curious.

question: They destroyed the simulator room and you with it.
answer: The Kobayshi Maru scenario frequently wreaks havoc with students and equipment. As I recall you took the test three times yourself. Your final solution was, shall we say, unique?

question: It had the virtue of never having been tried.
answer: Yours was not a solution which would have occurred to a Vulcan mentality.

question: So you said at the time. Speaking of which, your protg's first rare -- a trifle emotional --
answer: She's half Romulan, Jim. The admixture makes her more volatile than -- me, for example.

question: Than you. Yes, I see that. By the way, thank you for this.
answer: I know of your fondness for antiques.

question: 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...' Message, Spock?
answer: None of which I am consciously aware -- except, of course, happy birthday -- surely the best of times.

question: Hrummm... and where are you off to, now?
answer: The Enterprise. I must check in before your inspection. And you?

question: Home.
answer: Something oppresses you.

question: Does it have to be completely lifeless?
answer: Don't tell me you've got something.

question: We've picked up a minor energy flux reading on one dyno scanner.
answer: Damn! Are you sure? Maybe the scanner's out of adjustment --

question: I suppose it could be a particle of preanimate matter caught in the matrix...
answer: All right, let's get on the Comm-pic to Doctor Marcus. Maybe it's something we can transplant.

question: You know what she'll say...
answer: It might only be a particle of preanimate matter...

question: How can you let them pull that stuff on you? They're just lazy.
answer: And bored. I know. But maybe it IS something they can...

question: Come on, Mother, that's just the military mentality. Never put off tomorrow what you can put off today. If there's one atom of life...
answer: I know, I know...

question: Well, don't have kittens. Genesis is going to work. They'll remember you in a wreath with Newton, Einstein, Surak...
answer: Thanks a lot. No respect from my offspring --

question: Par for the course... you teaming up with me for bridge after dinner?
answer: Maybe...

question: Every time we have dealings with Starfleet, I get nervous. We're dealing with something that COULD be perverted into a dreadful weapon. Remember that overgrown boy scout you used to hang out with? That's exactly the --
answer: Listen, kiddo, Jim Kirk was many things, but he was never a Boy Scout...

question: Come. Bless me, doctor; and what beams you into this neck of the woods?
answer: 'Beware Romulans bearing gifts.' Happy Birthday...

question: Romulan Ale! Bones, you know this stuff is illegal --
answer: I only use it for medicinal purposes. Don't be a pring...

question: Twenty-two, eighty-three...
answer: Takes the stuff a while to ferment. Gimme. Now open the other one.

question: I'm almost afraid to. What did you bring me, contraband Klingon --
answer: More antiques for your collection -- Cheers!

question: Cheers. Bones, these are... charming.
answer: Four hundred years old. You don't find many with the lens still intact.

question: Uh -- what are they?
answer: For your eyes. For most patients of your age, I generally administer Retlax Five to restore flexibility of the lens.

question: But I'm allergic to Retlax.
answer: Exactly. Happy birthday. Slide them down your nose. Now look at me over the top. And you read printed matter through the bottom.

question: Amazing! I don't know what to say --
answer: Say thank you.

question: Thank you.
answer: Damn it, Jim, what the hell's the matter? Other people have birthdays. Why're we treating yours like a funeral?

question: Bones, I don't want to be lectured.
answer: What DO you want? Damn it, why isn't there a girl here? You know this has nothing to do with age. This is about you flying a goddamn computer console when you wanna be out hopping Galaxies.

question: Spare me your notions of poetry, please. We all have our assigned duties and...
answer: Bull. You're hiding -- hiding behind the rules and regulations --

question: And who am I hiding from?
answer: From yourself, Admiral.

question: Don't mince words, Bones; tell me what you really think.
answer: I'm your doctor and I'm your friend, Jim. Get back your command. Get it back before you really do grow old. Before you turn into part of this collection.

question: Are you sure these are the coordinates?
answer: Captain, this is the garden spot of Ceti Alpha VI --

question: I can hardly see --
answer: There's nothing, let's go --

question: They look like cargo carriers... What is it?
answer: A face! I saw -- it was like a child --

question: You're crazy -- !
answer: I saw it -- !

question: There's an air-lock. There's breathable atmosphere in here. What the hell is this? Did they crash? Where's the rest of the ship?
answer: I told you! I told you I saw a --

question: Ssssh!
answer: Botany Bay -- oh no!

question: What's the matter -- ?
answer: Captain, we've got to get out of here -- now! Damn! Hurry!

question: But the child --
answer: Never mind! Hurry!

question: What do you want with us? I demand --
answer: You are in a position to demand nothing, sir. I, on the other hand, am in a position to grant nothing. What you see is all that remains of the ship's company and the crew of the Botany Bay, marooned here fifteen years ago by Captain James T. Kirk.

question: Listen to me -- you men and women --
answer: Save your strength, Captain, these people have sworn to live and die at my command two hundred years before you were born. Do you mean he... ... never told you the tale? To amuse you, Captain? Never told you how the Enterprise picked up the Botany Bay, lost in space from the year 1996, myself and the ship's company in cryogenic freeze?

question: I've never even met Admiral Kirk --
answer: Admiral? He didn't tell you how Admiral Kirk sent seventy of us into exile on this barren sand heap with only the contents of these cargo bays to sustain us?

question: Admiral? He didn't tell you how Admiral Kirk sent seventy of us into exile on this barren sand heap with only the contents of these cargo bays to sustain us?
answer: You lie! On Ceti Alpha V there was life, a fair chance to --

question: This is Ceti Alpha V! Ceti Alpha VI exploded six months after we were left here. The shock shifted the orbit of this planet and everything was laid waste. Admiral Kirk never bothered to check on our progress. It was only the fact of my genetically engineered intellect that enabled us to survive! On earth, two hundred years ago, I was a prince, with power over millions -- now, like Prometheus I have been left by Admiral Kirk to digest my own entrails.
answer: Captain Kirk was your host! You repaid his hospitality by trying to steal his ship and murder him.

question: And I'll wager he never told you about his shipmate, the beautiful and courageous Lieutenant McGiver, who gave up everything to join me in exile. OUT OF LOVE. And see how Admiral Kirk requited her devotion -- She's dead as earth! A plague upon you all. You didn't expect to find me. You thought this was Ceti Alpha VI. Why are you here? Why? No matter. You will soon tell me willingly enough. Let me introduce you to Ceti Alpha V's only remaining indigenous life form; what do you think? They've killed twenty of my people, including my beloved wife. Oh, not all at once and not instantly, to be sure. Their young enter through the ears and wrap themselves around the cerebral cortex. This has the effect of rendering the victim extremely susceptible to suggestion. Later, as they grow, follows madness, paralysis -- and death. These are pets, of course -- not quite domesticated.
answer: Khan, listen to me! Captain Kirk was only doing his duty! You --

question: Enterprise, this is Admiral Kirk's party on final approach.
answer: I really must thank you.

question: I am delighted; any chance to go aboard Enterprise, however briefly, is always an excuse for nostalgia.
answer: I cut your new orders personally. By the end of the month, you'll have your first command

question: Thank you, sir. I've looked forward to this for a long time.
answer: You've earned it. But I'm still grateful to have you at the helm for three weeks. I don't believe these kids can steer.

question: You've earned it. But I'm still grateful to have you at the helm for three weeks. I don't believe these kids can steer.
answer: Prepare for Admiral's inspection. Open the Air Lock.

question: Permission to come aboard, Captain?
answer: Welcome aboard, Admiral. I believe you know my trainee crew. Certainly they have come to know you.

question: Ah. And who is this?
answer: Midshipman First Class Peter Preston, engineers mate, SIR.

question: Your first training voyage, Mr. Preston?
answer: Yes, SIR.

question: He's not what I expected, Sir.
answer: What did you expect, Lieutenant?

question: He's very human.
answer: We can't all be perfect, Saavik. You must control your prejudices and remember that as a Vulcan as well as a Romulan you are forever a stranger in an alien land. Around you are humans, and as a member of the Starfleet you are unlikely ever to escape their presence or their influence. You must learn to tolerance in addition to all else I have taught you. Tolerance is logical.

question: Midshipman, you're a tiger.
answer: My sister's youngest, Admiral. Crazy to get to space.

question: Every young boy's fancy. I seem to remember it myself. Very well. Mr. Scott, are your engines capable of handling a minor training cruise?
answer: Give the word, Admiral.

question: Mr. Scott, the word is given.
answer: Aye, sir.

question: Very well, Mr. Saavik, clear all moorings.
answer: Aye, sir. All moorings are clear, Captain.

question: Thank you, Mr. Saavik. Lieutenant, how many times have you piloted a Starship out of Spacedock?
answer: Never, sir.

question: Take her out, Mr. Saavik.
answer: Aye, sir.

question: It's not much different from Enterprise. When I was a guest aboard her some years ago, Captain Kirk kindly allowed me to memorize her technical manuals. And now, Mr. Chekov, let us review
answer: Beyond what I told you, sir, it is classified information.

question: Umm. And would Admiral Kirk have access to such information?
answer: I would think so, sir. He's on the Fleet General Staff.

question: Then to whom do you report directly regarding Genesis?
answer: To Doctor Marcus, the civilian director of the experiments on Space Laboratory Regula I.

question: On the screen, please, Jedda.
answer: ... come in, please. This is Reliant calling Regula I. Repeat. This is USS Reliant --

question: Commander, we are receiving. This is Regula I. Go ahead.
answer: Dr. Marcus... good. We're en route to you and should be there in three days.

question: En route? Why? We weren't expecting you for another three months. Has something happened? Has something happened? Do you read us?
answer: All went well. Nothing has happened. Ceti Alpha VI has checked out.

question: I still don't under --
answer: We have received new orders. Upon our arrival at Regula I, all materials of Project Genesis will be transferred to this ship for immediate testing at Ceti Alpha VI.

question: Will you please be quiet! Commander Chekov, this is completely irregular. Who gave the order you are quoting? Who gave the order?
answer: The order comes from Starfleet command, Dr. Marcus, direct from the General Staff.

question: But Genesis is a civilian project, under my control --
answer: I have my orders.

question: Will you please be quiet! We must have order here. This has to be some sort of mistake.
answer: Mistake? We're all alone here. They waited until everyone was on shift-leave to do this. Reliant is supposed to be at our disposal, not vice-versa.

question: I know, but --
answer: I've tried to warn you. Scientists are always pawns of the military --

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: Lieutenant, are you wearing your hair differently?

question: It is still regulation, Admiral. May I speak, sir?
answer: Lieutenant, self-expression does not seem to be one of your problems.

question: I wish to thank you for the high efficiency rating.
answer: You earned it.

question: I did not think so.
answer: You're bothered by your performance on the Kobayashi Maru.

question: I failed to resolve the situation.
answer: There is no correct resolution. It is a test of character.

question: May I ask how you dealt with the test?
answer: You may ask, Lieutenant. That was a little joke.

question: Humor... that is a difficult concept ... it is not logical...
answer: We learn by doing, Lieutenant. You want my advice?

question: Yes.
answer: Take the test again.

question: Admiral Kirk --
answer: Kirk here.

question: I have an urgent CommPic from Space Lab Regula I for the Admiral. Dr. Carol Marcus.
answer: In my quarters, Uhura.

question: Jim... read me? Can you read me?
answer: Message breaking up, Carol. What's wrong? What's wrong?

question: ... Can't read you... repeat...
answer: Repeat... what's wrong? What's wrong?

question: ... taking Genesis away from us...
answer: Taking Genesis? Who? Who is taking Genesis?

question: ... see you but can't hear. Did you... order...?
answer: What order? Who's taking Genesis?

question: ... Please help us, Jim... won't let them have... without proper... repeat... on whose authority...
answer: Carol!

question: Jim please --
answer: Uhura! What's happening? Damn it...

question: Mr. Sulu, go to Warp 5. We've got a problem. Something may be wrong at Regula I. We've been ordered to investigate.
answer: Regula I is a scientific research laboratory, if memory serves...

question: I told Starfleet all we had was a boatload of children but we're the only ship in the quadrant. Spock
answer: Like all living beings, Admiral each according to his gifts. The ship is yours.

question: That won't be necessary
answer: Excuse my presumption, but I do not agree. As a teacher on a training mission, I am content to command a Starship. If we are to go on actual duty, it is clear that the senior officer aboard must assume command.

question: But it may be nothing; garbled communications. Why don't you...
answer: You proceed from a false assumption. I am a Vulcan. I have no ego to bruise.

question: You are going to remind me that logic alone dictates your actions.
answer: I was going to remind you of nothing, least of all that which you know well. Your mistake, if I may be so bold, was promotion. Commanding a Starship is your first best destiny. Anything else is a waste of material.

question: I would not presume to debate you.
answer: That is wise. In any case, were I to invoke logic, logic clearly dictates that the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few.

question: Or the one.
answer: You are my superior officer. You are also my friend. I have been and always shall be yours.

question: Will you accompany me to the bridge?
answer: I'd best talk with Mr. Scott, first so that he may, in his own words, explain the situation to his cadets.

question: There are two possibilities, sir they are unwilling to respond, they are unable to respond.
answer: How far?

question: Twelve hours and forty-three minutes, present speed.
answer: Give up Genesis, she said. What in God's name does that mean? Give it up to whom?

question: It might help my analysis if I knew what Genesis was.
answer: Uhura, ask Dr. McCoy to join us in my quarters. Mr. Saavik, take the con.

question: But dear Lord, are we intelligent enough to -- Suppose, this thing were used where life already exists?
answer: It would destroy such life in favor of its new matrix --

question: It's new -- have you any idea what you're saying?
answer: I was not attempting to evaluate its moral implications, Doctor. As a matter of cosmic history, it has always been easier to destroy than to create --

question: Not anymore! Now you can do both at the same time! According to myth, the earth was created in six days. Watch out
answer: I don't dispute that in the wrong hands --

question: Chekov's on Reliant, isn't he?
answer: She's not responding...

question: Try the emergency channels...
answer: Enterprise to Reliant. Come in, Reliant.

question: Slow to one-half impulse power. Let's be friends...
answer: They're requesting visual communications, sir.

question: Let them eat static.
answer: They're still running with shields down.

question: They knew just where to hit us.
answer: WHO? Who knew just where to hit us? And why?

question: One thing is certain; we cannot escape on auxiliary power.
answer: Visual! Mr. Sulu, divert everything to the phasers --

question: Too late --
answer: Hang on! Scotty -- what's left?

question: Who the hell are they?
answer: Admiral... Commander Reliant is signaling. He wishes to discuss terms of our surrender.

question: On screen.
answer: Admiral --

question: You still remember, Admiral. I cannot help but be touched. Of course, I remember you.
answer: What is the meaning of this attack? Where is the crew of the Reliant?

question: Surely I have made my meaning plain. I mean to avenge myself upon you, Admiral. I've deprived your ship of power and when I swing round I mean to deprive you of your life -- -- But I wanted you to know first who it was who had beaten you
answer: Khan, listen to me -- if its me you want, I'll have myself beamed aboard. All I ask is that you spare my crew.

question: That is a most intriguing offer. Typical, I must say of your sterling character. Let me think. I make you a counter-proposal, I will agree to your terms, if in addition to yourself, you turn over to me all data and material regarding the project called Genesis.
answer: Genesis, what's that?

question: Don't play with me, Kirk, my hand is on the phaser control --
answer: Give me some time to recall the data on our computers --

question: If he hadn't, we'd be space by now.
answer: Admiral, this is Spock.

question: Yes, Spock.
answer: Engine room reports auxiliary power restored. We can proceed at impulse power.

question: Are you all right?
answer: Doctors lose patients sometimes. Damn. I'm still in the dark

question: At the moment that question takes a back seat to preventing him from laying his hands on it. You said it yourself; we're talking about a bang that would re-arrange the universe...
answer: There may still be time... you gave as good as you got.

question: Sensors, Captain?
answer: Scanners and sensors still inoperative. There's no way to tell what's inside the station.

question: And no way of knowing if Reliant is still in the area...
answer: Affirmative, Admiral.

question: ... Blind as a Tiberian Bat. What do you make of the plantoid beyond?
answer: Regula is class "D'. It consists of various remarkable ores. Essentially, a great rock in space.

question: Reliant could be hiding behind that rock.
answer: A distinct possibility.

question: There is no such regulation. All right, join the party. Mr. Spock, the ship is yours.
answer: Aye sir --

question: Establish a parking orbit around the station and send me a complete damage report when you've talked with Mr. Scott.
answer: Be careful, Jim...

question: Anything?
answer: Somebody left the unit on. If everyone else was dead, it implies that no one remained to turn it off. Those people back there bought escape time for Genesis with their lives.

question: It doesn't make sense. These coordinates are well within Regula -- a plantoid we know to be lifeless and airless.
answer: If Stage Two was completed, it was underground -- she said it was going to be underground.

question: Stage Two of what?
answer: Kirk to Enterprise. Damage report, Spock?

question: Kirk to Enterprise. Damage report, Spock?
answer: Admiral, if we go by the book, like Lieutenant Saavik, hours could seem like days.

question: I read you, Captain. Let's have it.
answer: The situation is grave, Admiral. We won't have main power for six days at least. Auxiliary power has temporarily failed, but maybe we can restore that in two days. By the book, Admiral.

question: Meaning you can't even beam us back?
answer: Not at present.

question: Very well. Let's go.
answer: Go? Where are we going?

question: Where they went. Saavik.
answer: But what if they went -- nowhere?

question: You're the sonavabitch who committed mass murder up there.
answer: I'm Admiral Kirk...

question: We were still there, you dumb bastard! We could hear the screams all the way to the transporter room --
answer: Where's Dr. Marcus --

question: I'm Doctor Marcus!
answer: David --

question: Mother, go back!
answer: Jim --

question: Go back. I'm going to kill him.
answer: You do that and you'll have murdered your father.

question: Don't move -- any of you!
answer: Captain... We're waiting. What's the delay?

question: All is well, sir. You have the coordinates to beam up Genesis...
answer: First things first, Captain. Kill Admiral Kirk.

question: As your teacher Mr. Spock is fond of saying
answer: David was right, wasn't he? It's just to keep them busy.

question: Why? Why didn't you tell me?
answer: How can you ask me that? Were we together? Where we going to be? You had your world and I had mine. I wanted him in mine, not chasing through the universe with his father. He's a lot like you in many ways. Nothing I could do about it. He's smarter, of course; that goes without saying. Most of Genesis is really his. This is it, isn't it? We're never going to get out of here. Please. Tell me what you're feeling.

question: There's a man I haven't seen in fifteen years who thinks he's killed me. You show me a son who'd almost be happy to help him. My son. My life that could have been and wasn't. What am I feeling? I'm feeling old -- worn out.
answer: Let me show you something that will make you feel young -- young as when the world was new. He'll be all right. Come.

question: You did this -- in a day?!
answer: The matrix formed in a day. The life forms grew later -- at a wildly accelerated rate. Can I cook or can't I?

question: What are you looking at?
answer: The Admiral's son.

question: Don't you believe it.
answer: Oh, I believe it. What are you looking at?

question: And almost got tossed out of the Academy...
answer: How?

question: I reprogrammed the simulation so it was possible to rescue the ship.
answer: WHAT?

question: I changed the conditions of the test. I received a commendation for original thinking. I don't like to lose.
answer: Then -- you never faced that situation -- faced death...

question: They're inoperative below C-deck.
answer: What IS working around here?

question: Not much, Admiral. We have partial main power...
answer: That's it?

question: Why are we slowing?
answer: We daren't follow them into the nebula, sir -- our shields will be useless...

question: Full impulse power!
answer: No sir! We have Genesis -- Whatever you want --

question: Man the weapons console, Mr. Chekov. Spock?
answer: Sporadic energy readings port side, aft. Could be an impulse turn.

question: He won't break off now. If he followed me this far he'll be back. But from where...?
answer: He's intelligent, but not experienced. His pattern indicates two dimensional thinking...

question: It's the Genesis Wave!
answer: What?

question: He's on a build up to detonation!
answer: How soon --

question: We encoded four minutes --
answer: We'll beam aboard and stop it --

question: You can't!
answer: Scotty, I need warp speed in three minutes or we're all dead! Scotty! Saavik, get us out, best speed!

question: Oh, God. Spock!
answer: The ship -- out of danger?

question: Yes --
answer: Don't grieve, Admiral -- it's logical

question: ... the good of the few...
answer: Or the one. I never took the Kobayashi Maru test -- until now. What do you think of my solution?

question: Spock...!
answer: I have been -- and always will be -- your friend... Live. Long. And. Prosper.

question: Lieutenant. After you dismiss the company, you will take the watch. Set course for Ceti Alpha V and we'll pick up survivors.
answer: Aye, sir.

question: I'll be in my quarters if needed, but I would prefer...
answer: Understood, sir.

question: Dismiss the company. Yes... come.
answer: I don't mean to intrude.

question: Uh, no... I should be on the bridge.
answer: Are you running away from me?

question: I suppose I was. I poured a drink. Would you like it?
answer: No. I -- I guess I'm not what you expected.

question: I didn't expect anything.
answer: That makes two of us. Lieutenant Saavik was right

question: Not like this -- no. I haven't faced death, I cheated death. I tricked my way out of death and patted myself on the back for my ingenuity. I know nothing.
answer: You knew enough to tell Saavik that how we face death is at least as important as how we face life --

question: It was just words.
answer: But good words. That's where ideas begin. Maybe you should listen to them.

question: I'm trying, David.
answer: So am I. My friends were killed, too.

question: I am truly sorry.
answer: I was wrong about you. And I'm sorry.

question: Is that what you came here to say?
answer: Mainly. And also that I'm proud -- very proud -- to be your son.

question: Admiral on the bridge!
answer: As you were, Mr. Saavik.

question: Aye, sir. On course to Ceti Alpha. All is well.
answer: Good, I believe you already know my, uh, son -- Yes, well, why don't you show him around and...
